title: Formula for Finding kth Percentile
text: Remember the formula for finding the kth Percentile. We want to know three values: $$k=the$$ kth percentile, usually given to you; $$i=the$$ index (ranking or position of the data value), what we normally want to find; $$n=the$$ total number of data. Then, we can use the formula to calculate $$i=\frac{k}{100} \left(n+1\right)$$. If i is an integer, we use the data at the ith position in the ordered data. If i is not an integer, we then round i down and up to the nearest integers and take the average of these two.

title: Determining k (Percentile)
text: What is the kth percentile we want to determine?

title: Determining n (Total Number of Data)
text: What is n, the total number of data in the set?

title: Determining i (Desired Index)
text: Using the Formula for Finding the kth Percentile, what is i?

title: Determining the position of the data
Determining the 70th Percentile
text: What is the data value in the 21st position of the ordered data set? This is the 70th percentile.
